abstract: Two studies published in Journal of the American Medical Association find that fewer men are being screened for prostate cancer, resulting in drop in early-stage detection; it is too early to tell if changes will affect death rates from disease.
lead_paragraph: The declines “could have significant public health implications,” one study said, and almost certainly result from a panel’s recommendation against the hotly debated test.

headline.main: Early Prostate Cancer Cases Fall Along With Screening
headline.print_headline: Prostate Advice Is Put in Doubt by New Study

snippet: The declines “could have significant public health implications,” one study said, and almost certainly result from a panel’s recommendation against the hotly debated test.
